fullText: The Cottage tries to emphasize the fizz, but nobody remembered to shake the soda can beforehand. It’s full of explanations, light on mess
showScoreExcerpt: “There’s a fizz that bubbles up near the end of a door-slamming farce when the characters, one by one, have to explain to one another what’s actually going on...’The Cottage' tries to emphasize the fizz, but nobody remembered to shake the soda can beforehand. It’s full of explanations, light on mess.”

keyPhrases.quote: tries to emphasize the fizz, but nobody remembered to shake the soda can beforehand
It's full of explanations, light on mess
There's a fizz that bubbles up near the end of a door-slamming farce

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The critic uses vivid metaphors to describe a production that fails to deliver the energy and chaos expected from farce, emphasizing structural problems over any redeeming qualities. | GPT-4o-mini: The review expresses significant disappointment in the execution of the farce, indicating a lack of engagement and enjoyment.

bwwExcerpt: The most interesting thread of The Cottage involves Rustin’s trying to work against the knee-jerk sexism of the genre as Sylvia slowly discovers that her happiness shouldn’t depend on the men around her. Fittingly for the 1920s setting, Rustin even weaves in a few references to the women’s-suffrage movement. But because the characters, for the sake of the comedy, have already become so abstract, Rustin’s points remain abstract too. As is true of so much in the play, you can see the turn coming a
